Description: Terracotta mould-made protome-bust of a woman in Archaic East Greek style, wearing stephane (diadem) and veil. The outline of the face is round and full, with long pointed oval almond shaped (archaic style) eyes placed at an angle. Nostrils indicated. Traces of white coating, possibly paint. Red-brown clay with sand inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the National Museum of Scotland. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This figure follows an archaic Greek style, though is late Archaic or early Classical in style. Reminiscent of style and fabric of a Punic/Phoenician copy of a Greek protome dating to the early 5th century BC in Tharros (British Museum ME 1856,1223.459). This piece is from a more complicated free standing piece.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.003) (Phase 3)
